botanical_details.genus: Brassicas can be annual, biennial or perennial plants, most are upright with alternate, often glaucous leaves, long taproots and clusters of cross-shaped, yellow or white flowers. The genus includes a number of species bred to produce food crops, such as cabbages, turnips, mustards and oilseed rape, as well as others grown for their ornamental value

how_to_grow.cultivation: Thin out seedlings to prevent overcrowding; the thinnings can be used in a salad. Keep the plants well-watered during the growing season to avoid bolting. See 'growing pak choi' in vegetable cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by seed sown outdoors from April to July in a sunny position in fertile soil. Sow seed thinly in rows 30cm apart. Earlier and later sowings, to produce baby leaves, can also be made under cloches or fleeces in mild areas
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to flea beetle
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to powdery mildews
